Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Systematics and Diversification of the Aderidae (Coleoptera: Tenebrionoidea): Elucidating the Evolution of Sexual Dimorphism
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Aderidae is a moderately diverse beetle family containing 1,200 species that inhabit all continents except Antarctica and are currently classified into 45 genera. Aderidae also has a rich fossil record in Baltic, Dominican, Mexican, and Lebanese amber inclusions. Many species exhibit varying degrees of sexual dimorphism, several inhabit cave systems, and some are social parasites of termites. This study will be the first to investigate evolutionary relationships within this family using modern molecular systematic methods. This project specifically emphasizes currently under-utilized morphological imaging methods. The morphological data from these fossil specimens will be evaluated and included in analyses in order to examine the historical timing of evolutionary events, such as the evolution of sexual dimorphism.

This project will produce a revised classification for the Aderidae in addition to the discovery and description of extant and fossil species. The complete integration of data from extant and fossil specimens makes this an exemplar multi-disciplinary study that will investigate the diversification of these beetles within a temporal framework. Results from this research will be broadly disseminated through presentations at research conferences and local science caf√©s to promote scientific awareness in the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, at the broadest level, focused on the incredible biodiversity of our planet, ultimately seeking to understand how species form and persist through evolutionary time. Why do some groups of organisms have so many species while others have so few? What characteristics are correlated with highly diverse groups? Particularly of interest are those physical features that are different between the sexes (i.e. sexual dimorphism). To address these questions, an evolutionary approach was used to examine the most species-rich group of animals on the planet – beetles. The project particularly focused on the higher-level classification, rates of DNA sequence evolution, and estimating the time between the divergence of groups in a little-known and understudied family of beetles called the puppet beetles. This work emphasized an integrative global perspective by examining exemplars from across the world fauna. Both DNA sequence data and morphological features were analyzed and specimens from natural history collections were extensively used.

Phylogenetic Relationships & Classification. This research focused on generating the first DNA sequence-based phylogenies for the puppet beetles. Even though there are over 1000 species in the group, comprising a substantial portion of our planet’s biodiversity, not a single phylogenetic tree has ever been produced for them. This work emphasized an integrative, multi-regional approach and examined exemplars from the throughout the world fauna, resulting in a project with a global perspective. Phylogenetic analyses consistently recovered higher-level relationships between major groups of puppet beetles that will be the basis for a modern classification for the family. Researchers worldwide will be using these findings to explore additional puppet beetle biodiversity, enabling the description of numerous new species of beetles that can be placed into the revised classification.

Fossils & Divergence Time. This project incorporated Dominican, Baltic, and Lebanese amber fossils, directly integrating their morphological characters in a total-evidence phylogeny for computation of divergence time estimates. When did major clades of puppet beetles evolve and when did sexual dimorphism within the family evolve? This project resulted in the first descriptions of fossil puppet beetle species. Fossils were examined with both standard light microscopy and also phase-contrast X-ray synchrotron microtomography (PPC-SRμCT), which enabled three dimensional image reconstructions of beetle specimens that were encased in amber millions of years ago.

Sexual Dimorphism & Evolution. Sexual dimorphism or differences in shared traits between males and females is a widespread and well-recognized phenomenon in the animal kingdom. Sexual dimorphism is generally thought to be the result of sexual selection, which is considered a powerful driving force in speciation that can result in genetic isolation and increase diversification rates. But since the writings of Darwin and Wallace, the model of the sequence of evolution of sexually dimorphic traits has been debated. Darwin proposed that the ancestral state of the two sexes would be monomorphic, i.e. identical and without ornamentation, with dimorphism arising through the gain of the exaggerated trait in only one sex. Whereas Wallace proposed a monomorphic ancestral state in which both sexes exhibit the ornamentation and then dimorphism evolves by loss in a single sex.
